awd_titl_txt: Binary Black Holes at the Extremes in the Era of Gravitational Wave Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in gravitational wave detector data analysis and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. This research project is devoted to the analysis and modeling of gravitational waves. These ripples in the very fabric of space and time are produced when the densest objects in the Universe -- such as black holes and neutron stars -- orbit and collide. The detection of gravitational waves by the NSF-funded LIGO and European Virgo collaborations has opened up a new window on the Universe, revealing previously invisible events like pairs of black holes merging. Members of the Austin Relativity group will participate in the analysis of gravitational waves as members of the LIGO collaboration, helping to infer the properties of the sources of these ripples. To ensure the maximum scientific benefit from the detection of gravitational waves, models for how these waves are produced require continuing refinement. Members of the research group will perform numerical simulations on supercomputers in order to explore the orbit and collision of pairs of black holes. The focus will be on extreme configurations -- such as systems with very unequal masses and complicated orbits -- with the goal of making new connections to pen and paper approximations for how gravitational waves are produced in these cases. These research activities will provide training for graduate students in high-performance computing and data analysis, skillsets which are in great demand and of great benefit to society. In addition, members of the group will engage in outreach activities in order to educate and inspire the public about this new field of physics and astronomy. Finally, members of the group will participate in outreach to high school women, in order to promote diversity within STEM fields.

This project focuses on the study of binary black holes with significantly different masses, whose gravitational waves are challenging to model. This project will connect numerical simulations of these binaries with analytical approximations which are capable of modeling binaries with very unequal masses, in particular the self-force approximation. Targeted simulations will test the self-force and other approximations, provide independent verification of their predictions, reveal their limitations, and point to refined approaches for use in GW science. The key tool for making comparisons will be invariant quantities, such as the redshift factor and orbital frequency shifts of the black holes. Advances in modeling these binaries will have immediate benefits for the current era of GW detectors, and will be crucial for the success of future, space-based missions. In addition, the PI and other members of the research group will directly participate in the analysis of gravitational waves. Members of the group measure the properties of these binaries which produce these waves using Bayesian parameter estimation. These inferences are a crucial first step in the use of gravitational wave detections for understanding the population of binary black holes, inferring the nuclear equation of state from observations of binary neutron stars, testing the theory of relativity, and using gravitational waves to measure cosmic expansion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported contributions to the LIGO Scientific Collaboration as well as independent research by the PI?s group. Under this award, our group participated in the transformative research carried out by the LIGO Scientific Collaboration during the award period. LIGO and its partner collaborations use kilometer-scale laser interferometers to detect gravitational waves. These ghostly ripples in the fabric of space and time are produced strongly by the orbits and collisions of ultra-dense objects like neutron stars and black holes. Our group assisted in both the detection and analysis of waves from such binaries during LIGO?s third observational campaign. We helped to measure the source properties of 79 newly detected gravitational wave signals in this time. These signals were used to test Einstein?s theory of gravity in highly dynamic circumstances, better understand the dense matter inside of neutron stars, map out the lives and deaths of massive stars, and measure the expansion of our Universe in new ways. These events included a number of new discoveries which challenged expectations. These include the detection of an especially massive pair of merging black holes, and a puzzling system with very unequal masses. The third observational campaign also reported the first confident detections of systems composed of neutron stars paired with black holes, which in the future can yield insights into the composition of neutron stars and provide a new probe of our cosmic history.

Our group also investigated the modeling of gravitational wave signals, by comparing the results of numerical simulations of orbiting black holes to ?pen-and-paper? approximations. We focused on an approximation method that assumes the black holes have very different masses, using the formalism of self-force. Our results contribute to a growing body of evidence which shows that this approach remains applicable to systems with nearly equal masses. This is the case for most systems detected by current gravitational wave observatories like the twin LIGO detectors. Our work motivates further development and application of this approach to the modeling of gravitational waves. On top of this, our group investigated a variety of other theoretical and data analysis questions which arose during the award period, including developing new gravitational wave search methods, new tests of relativity, and faster approaches to data analysis. 

This award also supported activities that broadly benefitted society, through student training and public outreach and education. This award supported research going into three PhD theses, and helped to train a number of additional students. Our group communicated the excitement of gravitational waves and what the community is learning about black holes to the public on several occasions. We also helped launch a novel series of public outreach events in the Austin area, and produced a Science Summary describing the results of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration.

In summary, the activities supported by this award enhanced our understanding of some of the most extreme and mysterious objects in our Universe: black holes and neutron stars. Gravitational waves provide a unique window onto these systems, which may be otherwise invisible, but which strongly warp the very fabric of space and time. Continued investigation of these objects through the gravitational waves they emit provides a deeper understanding of the nature of gravity and the cosmos we live in.
